Anaesthesia & Intensive Care: What is an anaesthesiologist? What is the job scope?

An anaesthesiologist is a doctor specialized in administering anaesthesia for surgery. They ensure your vital signs are stable during surgery, manage your level of consciousness, and address any problems that arise. They also manage postoperative pain and care for patients in ICU, optimizing them for surgery.
What are the risks associated with anesthesia?

The Department of Anesthesiology has advanced anesthesia safety for patients. Common side effects include headache, pain at the injection site, nausea, and vomiting. Many risks are mitigated through specific anesthetic approaches, including regional anesthesia.

You will receive instructions about eating and drinking from the nurse the day before surgery. If you are warded, refrain from eating at least six hours before the procedure to reduce the risk of aspiration, which can cause significant damage. Follow preoperative instructions carefully.
What medications should I take on the day of surgery?

Discuss your medications with your physician or surgeon before surgery. Patients scheduled for ambulatory surgery will be contacted by a daycare nurse before surgery to address medication questions. If unsure, bring your medications with you on the day of surgery.
Can my allergies interfere with anesthesia?
It is vital to inform your anesthesiologist of any allergies. Bring your allergy card if you have one. If needed, an allergy test may be conducted before you receive a surgery date.
Dietetics & Food Services: Can I see the dietitian for nutrition counseling?
Yes. You need to get a referral letter from the medical doctors to receive service from the dietitian. For outpatients, dietetic service is based on appointment in the Diet Clinic.
Where is the location for Diet Clinic for outpatients?
The Diet Clinic is located at level 2 of the Specialist Complex and Ambulatory Care Center (SCACC).
Will patients be provided with enteral product (milk formula) upon discharge?
Enteral products (milk formula) will not be provided upon discharge. If patients still require the enteral formula, they will need to purchase it based on the dietitian’s recommendation.
Are food provided in the ward during my treatment and am I given a choice?

Yes. Food will be provided based on orders from the ward. The menu includes standard or therapeutic diets based on patients’ medical conditions. First-class patients can choose from the diet menu provided.
Can I bring my own food from outside when I am receiving treatment in the ward?
No. Food will be provided by the hospital based on treatment and recovery needs. If you wish to bring food from outside, you must obtain permission from the ward.
Hospital Supervisory: Where is the wheelchair counter location if I want to use the service?
Patients/relatives can get wheelchair service at the entrance of the SCACC building located next to the ground floor motor park.
Can I use a wheelchair service at the SCACC building?
Patients can access the service if they are unable to walk and have an appointment at the SCACC building.
How do I get a wheelchair service?
Patients/relatives will need to leave their identification documents such as a work pass or driver's license for the purpose of registering a wheelchair at the counter.
When does the time for wheelchair service start?
Wheelchair service counter hours are from 7:00 am to 4:30 pm, except on weekends and public holidays.
Do I have to pay for the service?
No need. The service provided is free of charge.
What should I do in the event of any damage or loss of a borrowed wheelchair?
Patients/relatives should be responsible for reporting to the staff at the wheelchair service counter in the event of loss or damage to the wheelchair for follow-up action.
Who can I contact if I have any questions regarding the wheelchair service?
Patients/relatives can call 03-2615 5555 ext 7016 (Bahagian Penyeliaan Hospital) for any questions regarding the service.
Library: What are the library opening hours?
The library is open Monday to Friday from 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. The library will be closed on public holidays and on Saturday and Sunday.
I do not work for HKL. Is it possible for me to utilize your library services?

Where is the location of your library?

How can I access MOH Virtual Library?

How can I get articles from journals not subscribed by the Library?

Patient should be assessed by their primary doctor first, and referral should be made by the specialist to the Nuclear Medicine Department. The referral form will be vetted by Nuclear Medicine doctors according to indication, urgency, and availability. Appointment date and time will be updated in the department system and patients will be informed.
What are the documents required to get fee waiver for scans or treatments?
Social welfare card, zakat document, OKU card, pensioner card, school letter, and guarantee letter (GL).
Is the radioactive material used in nuclear medicine safe for the patient and surrounding people?

Before any study/treatment with radioactive material, patients will see the doctor for assessment to ensure fitness for investigation/treatment. Indication, safety, and radiation precautions will be explained. The dose will be calculated accurately and administered according to guidelines to ensure safety for the patient and surrounding people.

Occupational Therapy: When is the registration/operation time at Occupational Therapy Department?

Oral & Maxillofacial Surgery: Can this clinic accept Walk-In patients for dental check-up?
No. We only accept patients with a referral letter. Patients with no medical illness will have to go to the nearest government clinic for dental check-up.
Can I get filling & scaling done in Oral & Maxillofacial Department, HKL?

Both treatments are provided to patients referred to us with chronic medical illnesses such as heart disease, hypertension, diabetes, and cancer. Healthy patients can receive dental treatment at the nearest Government Clinic.
Can I do tooth implant and what is the cost?

Yes, but with a referral letter. The cost for the implant ranges from RM3000 to RM4000 depending on the type of implant used. Not all cases referred for implants are suitable for treatment. The Oral Surgeon will conduct examinations before starting treatment.
Can I bring my child for dental treatment?

Where should I go with referral letter addressed to Oral Pathology & Oral Medicine Clinic?

Otorhinolaryngology: What is the ORL Outpatient clinic schedule?

The outpatient clinics are scheduled every Tuesday, Wednesday, and Friday. Allergic clinic is on Thursday. FNAC Clinic is on Monday. Preoperative Assessment Clinic is on Monday and Thursday. Emergency cases will be seen on the same day at the Emergency Department.
When are the operation days for ORL patients?

Elective operations are scheduled on Monday and Thursday in the General Operation Theater. Surgeries are also provided on Saturday mornings according to schedule. Daycare surgery services are provided every Monday for eligible patients.
Do I need to get a referral letter?
Yes, all referrals to the Specialist Clinic require a referral letter.
When is the most appropriate time to undergo a tonsillectomy?

Tonsillectomy is advised if:1. Recurrent tonsillitis (more than 5 times a year).2. History of peritonsillar abscess.3. Obstructive Sleep Apnea due to Tonsillar Hypertrophy.4. Suspected tonsillar malignancy.5. Surgery is performed when the patient is healthy and not experiencing fever or sore throat.
I already have an appointment with the Audiologist/Speech Therapist, do I have to see an ORL Specialist as well?
Yes, our ORL doctors will see patients as required.
What are the preparations needed before undergoing an operation?

Preoperative preparations include:1. Explanation of surgery risks.2. Surgery date assigned (1 week to 3 months).3. Required tests (e.g., blood tests, ECG).4. Referral to Anaesthesiology.5. Reassessment appointment if healthy.6. Admission one day prior to surgery; earlier for patients with comorbidities.7. No valuables allowed.
Otorhinolaryngology - Audiology: It depends on the type of hearing loss (sensorineural, conductive, or mixed). Usually, sensorineural hearing loss cannot be cured, while conductive hearing loss may be treatable.
Do I have to wear a hearing aid if I have hearing impairment?
It is strongly advised for patients with disabling hearing impairment. Hearing aids amplify sound to a level that can be heard better, improving quality of life.
Do I have to wear the hearing aid in both ears?
If there is bilateral hearing impairment, it is best to wear hearing aids in both ears. However, you can choose to wear one first.
How much does a hearing aid cost?
The cost depends on the type and technology of the device, generally ranging from RM1,000 to RM10,000 for one ear.
Can I apply for financial aid to purchase the hearing aid?
Yes. Government employees or pensioners can apply through the Public Service Department. Others will be referred to the Department of Social Welfare for assistance options.
What if I have an issue with the hearing aid after fitting?
There will be a follow-up appointment after fitting to optimize the hearing aid settings.
Can I remove the hearing aid after fitting?
Yes, hearing aids can be removed when bathing or sleeping, but it is advisable to wear them for at least 8 hours a day.
Otorhinolaryngology - Speech Therapy: Factors include:(a) Hearing problems(b) Lack of language stimulation(c) Abnormal intraoral structure(d) Lack of playmates(e) Lack of interaction with family(f) Overly focused on academics under 4 years(g) Gadget and television addiction(h) Lack of play options at home.
When is the best time to start speech therapy for speech sound disorder?

Speech therapy for speech sound disorder will be conducted if:(a) No hearing impairment(b) Child understands and speaks(c) Child is 5 years old(d) Child can speak more than 5 words in a sentence but has articulation difficulties.
How do we take care of our voice?
(a) Avoid clearing throat, shouting, and loud talking in noise.(b) Learn proper singing techniques.
What can I do if my baby has difficulty in latching on or sucking?

(a) Get a detailed examination of the intraoral structure.(b) Choose suitable feeding equipment.(c) Ensure correct breastfeeding technique.(d) Offer the child preferred drinks.(e) Learn facial and mouth stimulation techniques.(f) Suckling skills are important under 2 years; introduce other feeding methods after that.
What are the symptoms of swallowing disorders?
(a) Loss of appetite(b) Pain on swallowing(c) Weight loss(d) Coughing during and after eating(e) Drooling(f) Dehydration.
Why is the waiting time for a speech therapy appointment so long?
(a) Limited number of speech therapists.(b) Each session takes 45-60 minutes.(c) Increasing rate of new referrals.(d) Long follow-up for each patient is typically two years.
(a) Evaluation, planning, and implementation of rehabilitation for speech, voice, and swallowing disorders.(b) Training parents/caretakers to practice therapy at home.
Pathology - Chemical Pathology: Can a regular urine collection container be used for urine catecholamine test?
No, because the 24 hours urine catecholamine test requires a special collection container containing preservatives.
When will my Thyroid Function Test (TFT) results be obtained?
Sample taken at the clinic will be sent to the main laboratory, HKL Pathology Department for analysis. LTAT for TFT is 3 working days.
Do I need to fast before taking blood for HbA1c test?
No fasting is required for HbA1c test.
When is the best time to take blood for Progesterone test?
Blood should be taken on the 21st day of menstruation.
Why was my test application rejected?
The application may be rejected if the sample was sent using the wrong tube, the sample was leaking, or the sample had hemolysis.
Pathology - Clinical Toxicology: Do I have to fast before my lab test?
Fasting is not required for tests analyzed in Clinical Toxicology Laboratory, but other tests may require fasting.
Why is my doctor ordering Therapeutic Drug Monitoring (TDM) test?
TDM is used to aid the management of drug therapy for the cure, alleviation, or prevention of disease.
What happens to my sample once I have provided blood?
Your sample will be dispatched to the main laboratory (Department of Pathology) of HKL for analysis in Clinical Toxicology Laboratory.
When will my clinician get the results?
LTAT is six hours for therapeutic drug monitoring, two working days for specific proteins, and five working days for tumor markers.
How may I see the results?
You may ask for the result from your clinician.
Where can I find the list of test and service hours?
Refer to HKL Pathology Service Book or website.
May I request for tumor markers for screening from my provider?
No. Screening for tumor markers is not recommended.
Can I eat medicine before appointment?
Follow the instructions given, especially for TDM, as it could affect result interpretation.
Pathology - Core Lab: Do I have to fast before my lab test?
Yes, for Fasting Blood Sugar and Fasting Serum Lipid Profile testing.
What happens to my sample once I have provided blood?
Your sample will be dispatched to the main laboratory (Department of Pathology) of HKL for analysis in Core Laboratory.
When will my clinician get the results?

The laboratory turn-around time is one hour for urgent requests, 2-3 hours for routine requests, and one working day for urine biochemistry tests. Lithium is analyzed on Mondays, Wednesdays, and Fridays only.
How may I see the results?
You may ask for the result from your clinician.
Where can I find the list of tests and service hours?
Refer to HKL Pathology Service Book or website.
How to send a sample for Mixing Study from Non-HKL hospital/clinics?
Mixing Test is performed by appointment and based on consultation with the Pathologist at 03-26155555 ext 5239, and the test is only offered during office hours.
Pathology - Cytology: What is a pap smear?
A type of test to detect abnormal cells in the cervix.
Why do you need to do a pap smear?
Detects cell changes at an early stage before it turns into cancer.
Who needs to do a pap smear?
All women who have had sexual intercourse, whether married or unmarried, aged 30-65 years.
When is the right time to do a pap smear?
Ideally in the middle of the menstrual cycle (10-15 days after the first day of menstruation).
Is pap smear painful?
The procedure may be less comfortable but should not be painful.
Frequency of pap smear?
Once for the first 2 years; if normal, repeat every 3 years.
Where are pap smear services offered?
In government or private hospitals and clinics.
Do I need to fast before the Fine Needle Aspiration Cytology (FNAC) procedure?
No fasting is required before performing the procedure.
How to take sputum specimen?
Patient should produce sputum by “deep cough.”
Where can I find the list of tests and service hours?
Refer to HKL Service Book or website.
How may I know the results?
You may ask for the result from your clinicians.

When will drug of abuse test results for Medicolegal cases be ready?
Results for Morphine & Cannabinoid tests will be ready in 10 days; other tests will be released within 60 days. Urgent cases will take 14 days.
Pathology - Heamatology: What is the most common haematology test performed on a patient?
Full Blood Count (FBC) is the most common test; it helps assess hemoglobin levels, white blood cell counts, and platelets.
What test will be carried out to detect thalassaemia status?
A basic screening tool using FBC is done for thalassaemia status. Abnormal results will be subjected to Hemoglobin Analysis, and DNA analysis may be performed if needed.
Where should I go for thalassaemia screening test?
At any government health clinic or certain private centers offering the service.
Can I undergo thalassaemia screening at Health Clinic without family history?
Yes, anyone can request a basic screening test (FBC).
What tests will be carried out if I am suspected of having leukemia?
Tests include Full Blood Picture (FBP) and Bone Marrow Aspiration & Trephine Biopsy to confirm leukemia.
Pathology - Histopathology: What kind of specimens are received in Histopathology lab?
Tissue samples obtained through biopsy or surgery. Body fluid, blood, and swab are not suitable for histopathology examination.
Where should specimens for Histopathology examination be sent to?
Counter no. 5 in the common receiving area (CRA), Pathology Department, HKL.
How should the specimens for Histopathology examination be sent?
Specimens must be sent immersed in 10% Neutral Buffered Formalin (NBF), unless contraindicated.
What are the contraindications to the usage of 10% NBF?
Certain specialized tests such as Enzyme histochemistry, muscle biopsies, and Immunofluorescence studies.
Wards and clinics in HKL can trace/access HPE reports via Laboratory Informative System (LIS).
How long is the turnaround time (TAT) duration for HPE reports?
TAT for small biopsies is 1 week, while for large specimens it is 1 month.
What happens to the specimens after Histopathology examination?
The specimens will be discarded 1 month after the final report has been validated.
Are patients allowed to retrieve their specimens?
Yes, patients are allowed to retrieve their specimens after the HPE reports are released.
What is the procedure to request HPE photos for presentation, discussion, etc.?
Contact the reporting pathologist and fill in a form at the histopathology office. TAT is 2 weeks from the date of request received.
Pathology - Microbiology: What is the role of the Microbiology Laboratory?
The main role of the microbiology laboratory is to conduct diagnostic tests to detect microorganisms from clinical specimens.
How long is the time period for bacterial culture?
Bacterial culture takes 18 to 48 hours; some bacteria like Mycobacterium tuberculosis may take longer than 48 hours.
What containers are used for bacterial culture?
Sterile containers that do not easily leak and break are used for bacterial cultivation.
What are the testing methods used to detect the virus?
Various methods are used to detect viruses, including viral DNA detection, antigens, or antibodies.
How long does it take to detect a virus?
About 3-7 working days, depending on the type of test offered.
Physiotherapy: What is Physiotherapy?
- Physio is the physiology that carries the meaning of function and therapy is care.- Physiotherapy means care of functional restoration.
What treatments are offered in Physiotherapy?

In general, physiotherapists focus on human limbs and the function of each part of the body. Physiotherapy ensures that the patient's body functions at an optimal level and helps reduce pain without the use of medications.
How if I want to get physiotherapy treatment?
To get treatment in physiotherapy, you must get a referral letter from a doctor/medical officer from any hospital, government, or private clinic.
After getting the referral letter, what do I need to do?
You should come to the physiotherapy department to get your appointment date. You are required to get an appointment date within 1 month from the date the referral letter is issued.
Why must be within a month to get an appointment date?

Every patient's condition can change due to physical activity. Over time, it is feared that your condition will change. This rule is to avoid contraindications in physiotherapy treatment that could harm the patient's condition.
If I come to pick up an appointment date, when will I get it?
An appointment will be given to you within 10 working days.
If I can’t come on that date, what should I do?
You can contact the Department of Physiotherapy using the contact number listed in your referral letter or appointment card.
What documents do I need to bring during a physiotherapy appointment?
You must bring a referral letter from a doctor, Identity Card, a copy of retiree card (if you are a retiree), and a copy of OKU card (if you have a disabled card).
How much is the treatment charge during physiotherapy treatment?

- Referred from government: Free for first-time citizens, seniors 60+, government retirees, and disabled cardholders. RM5.00 for each follow-up.- Referred from private: RM30.00 for the first treatment; subsequent charges depend on treatment.- Referred for noncitizens: RM120.00 for registration; charges depend on treatment.
What should I do if I have complications after treatment?
Please come to the Physiotherapy Department and meet the Physiotherapist who treated you for confirmation and further information.
Psychiatry: How do I receive treatment in the Psychiatry and Mental Health Department HKL?

Begin by getting an assessment and a referral letter from any qualified doctor (including nearby government health clinics or private general practitioners). Following that, please proceed (with the referral letter) to the Psychiatry and Mental Health Department HKL outpatient clinic located on the 4th floor of the Specialist Complex and Ambulatory Care Centre (SCACC) building during office hours.

For emergency cases only – which threatens danger to themselves or others, please proceed to the Psychiatry and Mental Health Department HKL outpatient clinic located on the 4th floor of the Specialist Complex and Ambulatory Care Centre (SCACC) building during office hours, or to the Emergency Department HKL outside office hours.
Must I be admitted to the ward to receive treatment?

Not all cases require admission to the ward. An assessment by a doctor from the Psychiatry and Mental Health Department, guided by the Mental Health Act 2001 and Mental Health Regulations 2010, will determine whether you will require inpatient care or merely outpatient clinic care using medications and/or psychotherapy (talking therapy).
What must I bring in preparation for admission to the psychiatry ward?

a) Basic personal needs and toiletries for daily use are allowed. b) Medications* for any of your other medical issues. c) Other items such as clothes* or money* can only be used on your way to the hospital or upon discharge from the ward. d) Food and drinks are available in the ward and outside food is not encouraged. *Please pass your items to the staff on duty during the early stages of your admission to the ward.
What objects are not allowed to be brought into the psychiatry ward by patients and their visitors?

Objects that cannot be brought into the ward include: a) Cigarettes, matches and lighters. b) Drugs and alcohol. c) Weapons and any object that can be fashioned into a weapon or might be dangerous such as knives, scissors, sticks, ropes et cetera. d) Jewellery or items with high monetary value. *Visitors will be asked to register to receive a visitor’s pass. Visitors might be searched for prohibited objects*.
Can I take pictures or record videos while I am in the psychiatry clinic or ward?

No. Any form of picture taking or video recording is not allowed in the psychiatry clinic or ward. This is to protect the privacy and comfort of patients, allowing the treatment process to run smoothly.

(By referral) Supervisors/Head of Nurses, Head of Department, and Medical Officers must complete the Counseling Psychology Service Referral Form for the staff and send the form to the Counseling Psychology Unit for registration.Referral form can be downloaded in Intranet Portal, HKL.
When can I meet the counselor?

Staff can meet the counselor during the counseling psychology office operating hours (except weekends and public holidays) as follows: Day: Monday – Thursday. Morning Session: 7.30 am – 01.00 pm. Evening Session: 2.00 pm – 5.00 pm. Day: Friday. Morning Session: 7.30 am – 12.15 pm. Evening Session: 2.45 pm – 5.00 pm. Counseling psychology clinic operating hours are from 8.00 am to 4.30 pm.
Where is the location of Counseling Psychology Unit?
Counseling Psychology Unit (UPsK) HKL is located at:Level 1 K8, Wisma Rekod/Kayu, Hospital Kuala LumpurCounseling room, Level 3, Specialist Complex And Ambulatory Care Centre (SCACC)
Is there any charges for counseling sessions and follow-up?
No. Counseling services in HKL are FREE of charges.
Is it safe for me to share issues with a counselor?

Counseling sessions are bound by the confidentiality ethics in the Counselors Act 1998 (Act 580) and Counseling Ethics unless issues involved that are detrimental to the client, others, and violations of existing laws. For referred cases, a counseling report will be issued to the referrer who applied.
Radiology: How can I obtain radiological services at the Radiology Department of HKL?
All radiological examinations at HKL must be referred either from the ward or clinic in HKL, Health Care Clinics (Public Clinic, KKM) or private centre following hospital policy.
Does Radiology Department provide FPP (Full Payment Patient) services?
At the moment, HKL Radiology Department DOES NOT provide FPP services.
Do out-patients need to make payments for radiological examinations at HKL?
Payment must be made through the Revenue Unit or requesting clinic according to the rate determined by the HKL Revenue Unit before undergoing radiological examination.
What preparations are required before undergoing a radiological examination?

Each radiological examination requires different preparations depending on the type, such as general radiography, CT Scan, MRI, angiography, mammography, bone densitometry (BMD), Orthopantomography (OPG), etc.
Can an outpatient radiological examination report be obtained immediately after the examination?

Only ultrasound examination reports will be provided immediately. For general radiographic exams, reports will be issued upon request. Specialized exams like CT, MRI, and mammography reports will be ready within 14 days.
